lines.text: And then the summer night smiled for the third time.

[to the audience]
For the sad, the depressed, the sleepless, the confused, the frightened, the lonely.
Why don't you write your memoirs?
My dear daughter, I was given this estate for promising not to write my memoirs.
Your father once threw me out of a window.
Was it open?
No, closed. I fell straight into a lieutenant colonel. He later became your father.
You said my father threw you out.
He became your father later, I said. Aren't you listening? My God I loved him so!
Which one?
The one who threw me out the window, of course. The other one was a dolt. He never could do anything amusing.
Why is youth so terribly unmerciful? And who has given it permission to be that way?
[Carl Magnus' wife has just told him that his mistress may be involved with someone else - he says to his wife]
I can tolerate my wife's infidelity, but if anyone touches my mistress, I become a tiger.
[Later, his mistress tells him that his wife may be unfaithful - he says to his mistress]
I can tolerate someone dallying with my mistress, but if anyone touches my wife, I become a tiger.
For once, I was truly innocent.
It must have been early in the evening.
I hit him on the head with the poker.
What did the Count say then?
We elected to part amicably.
Beware of good deeds. They cost far too much and leave a nasty smell.
Your children are very beautiful, especially the young girl.
The young girl is my wife, Mrs Armfeldt.
I believe you lead a very strenuous life, Mr Egerman.
If people knew the evil caused by listening to others, they would not care about listening and would be far happier.
I am tired of people. But that doesn't stop me from loving them.

[holding a cup of wine at a dinner table]
My dear children and friends. According to legend, the wine is pressed from grapes whose juice gushes out like drops of blood against the pale grape skin. It is also said that to each cask filled with this wine was added a drop of milk from a young mother's breast and a drop of seed from a young stallion. These lend to the wine secret seductive powers. Whoever drinks hereof does so at his own risk and must answer for himself.

I shall be faithful for at least seven eternities of pleasure, eighteen false smiles and fifty-seven tender whisperings without meaning. I shall remain faithful until the big yawn do us part. In short, I shall remain faithful in my way.
One can never protect a single human being from any kind of suffering. That is what makes one so tremendously weary.
I have fought 18 duels. Pistol, rapier, foil, spear, bow, poison, rifle. I have been wounded six times.
Men are horrible, vain and conceited. They have hair all over their bodies.
Who are we inviting? If they are actors, they will have to eat in the stables.
I shall remain faithful until the great yawn do us part.
We invoke love, call out to it, beg for it, cry for it, try to mimic it. We think we own it and tell lies about it.
But we don't have it.
No my sugar pie. We are denied the love of loving. We don't have the gift.
Nor the punishment.
